--Earlier today, players and coaching staff from Central and Northern High football teams met at Celery Flats and marched together down Westnedge to City Hall. They were joined by members of the Portage Police. The march was a call for the need for change, reform, and unity. The two high school teams that have been recently recognized as the “greatest rivals in the State of Michigan” put aside their differences and joined together in this global call for social justice.

As a contingency of the Unanticipated School Closure (part of the Summer Food Service Program), PPS is announcing that we will be able to service any student aged 18 or younger, as well as any special needs adults aged 26 or under who are part of an educational program.

Every week day Tuesday, March 17 - Thursday, April 2.

We are also able to serve meals for Saturday and Sunday, so on Friday, students can request a Friday, Saturday and Sunday lunch, along with a Saturday, Sunday, and Monday breakfast.

Since this is an emergency closure, some of the rules regarding meals have been relaxed: The child does not have to be present, and they do not have to eat on site.

post_text: We are loving the PPS history posts from our friends at the Portage District Library. Do you know anyone in this photo?
shared_text:
Portage District Library
July 11, 2019 at 7:43 AM ·

I know that it's summer, but I couldn't resist posting this image. Hey everyone, this is your Local Historian, Steve Rossio, with another Throwback Thursday. In this image, we see a delightful class of students posed in front of their elementary school. However, if one looks closer one will notice the Masonic emblems on the doors. Was this a field trip? Were these children of Masons? In fact, these students are attending class in the Masonic Lodge that once stood on the north side of Centre Street roughly across from today's Taco Bob's restaurant just east of South Westnedge. This wonderful lodge was actually built on the site of the old Portage Township Hall and Portage Grange building. In the 1940's and 1950's Portage Schools experienced overcrowding so they contracted out the use of the Masonic Lodge as an overflow classroom. Unfortunately, the lodge was demolished and today the site sits empty, waiting for redevelopment.

Hey everyone, this is your Local Historian, Steve Rossio, with another throwback Thursday. Here we see a group of Portage students waiting for the bus outside the Portage Township School located on South Westnedge (no longer standing) sometime in the very early 1950's. What I love about this photograph is that it shows that kids will be kids no matter what the era. At first glance, the students appear to be merely posing for the camera however...look closer. How many well-behaved kids are mugging it up for the photographer...making faces, picking their noses, etc. Now look at the teacher...hard to tell but she appears to be laying down the law on one student. This image shows that sometimes you need to really look at a photograph to understand what is actually going on.
